questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which device type is functioning in a degraded state?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
From: https://pyneng.readthedocs.io/en/latest/book/18_ssh_telnet/netmiko.html

Netmiko has several ways to send commands:

send_command - send one command
send_config_set - send list of commands or command in configuration mode
send_config_from_file - send commands from the file (uses send_config_set method inside)
send_command_timing - send command and wait for the output based on timer

All the best.

Selected Answer: CE
CE is correct

https://pyneng.readthedocs.io/en/latest/book/18_ssh_telnet/netmiko.html

Answer is still C+E
I just want to add that almost any configuration done in cisco devices implies accessing a submenu and sending a line like:
config terminal
 interface loopback1
 address XXX XXXX

So send_command is for "one-liners", you can do a "write" or "mkdir" but you need to handle the messages of confirmation, which is totally doable but more complicated than a "show", which is the best use of this send_command.

C+E are correct. send_command() is for read-only commands.
https://pyneng.readthedocs.io/en/latest/book/18_ssh_telnet/netmiko.html
See "sending commands" section

comments.content: send_command() is to display/fetch data, not config

def send_command
(
self, command_string, expect_string=None, delay_factor=1, max_loops=500, auto_find_prompt=True, strip_prompt=True, strip_command=True, normalize=True, use_textfsm=False, textfsm_template=None, use_ttp=False, ttp_template=None, use_genie=False, cmd_verify=True)
Execute command_string on the SSH channel using a pattern-based mechanism. Generally used for show commands. By default this method will keep waiting to receive data until the network device prompt is detected. The current network device prompt will be determined automatically.

it says send_command() is generally used for show commands. So I believe C and E are correct

discussion.content:
The correct answer is CD, send_command and send_config_set
https://ktbyers.github.io/netmiko/docs/netmiko/base_connection.html

questions.question_text: Which two Netmiko methods are used to configure a device? (Choose two.)

choices.B: All IOS XE operating systems include Ansible playbooks for basic system administration tasks.
choices.E: It does not require any modules of software except SSH to be loaded on the network device.
choices.A: Ansible playbooks are packaged and installed on IOS XE devices for automatic execution when an IOS device reboots.
choices.C: It is a device-independent method for automation and can be used with any type of device or operating system.
choices.D: Ansible playbooks can be written from the IOS XE EXEC command line to configure the device itself.

comments.content: Ansible is an angentless solution, so it's not installed on the Cisco devices

May I kindly ask why this is CE? Based on the link below, Cisco devices are already ready to be used for Ansible:

https://packetpushers.net/ansible-cisco-snmp/#:~:text=Ansible%20even%20support%20Windows%20servers,of%20modules%20use%20different%20protocols.&text=Two%20examples%20are%20Cisco%20Nexus,to%20be%20used%20from%20Ansible.

discussion.content: answer is CE

Selected Answer: AC
A-C is right answer.

Selected Answer: CE
Ansible doesnt use device agents, it only requiers SSH to connect to client device -> right answers are CE
Answer is CE
A is wrong, Ansible is agentless
Anser should be C & E

Selected Answer: CE
A is clearly wrong, for actions to be executed on reboot the only thing I can think of is Zero Touch Provisionning or passing a Python script through DHCP
Because it is agentless, Ansible can automate anything. It can automate devices with SSH, which is the most common option, but it also has support for HTTP APIs, NETCONF, and RESTCONF.

E) because on networking devices you don't expect python present, so all modules are executing on ansible control host.
From their documentation: "Unlike most Ansible modules, network modules do not run on the managed nodes."
Different approach compared to managing linux servers via ansible, where you have to provide path ( and install python ) on managed node.
Ansible is agentless, can't be A... B and D are also not true, which leaves C and E. I do agree that the answer could've been more decisive, but it's C and E

isnt Ansible agent-less and not installed on the network device ? Think that takes out A.. the wording of E is bizarre but think its CE... https://developer.cisco.com/docs/ios-xe/#!configuration-management-quick-start-guide/ansible
